title: Possible XSS vulnerability without a content security bypass

profile.name: Stripe
profile.about: Stripe is a technology company that builds economic infrastructure for the internet.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
Hi security team members,

Hope you are well and doing great :)

I found a **Possible XSS vulnerability in https://dashboard.stripe.com but I was not able to bypass a content security policy.**

Although, I don't have much knowledge about CSP and its bypasses. But, I read that you accept the XSS without a content security bypass. So, I'm reporting this to you.
> Please note that we do accept and reward submissions for valid cross-site scripting vulnerabilities even if they are not accompanied by a bypass of our content security policy. Cross-site scripting vulnerabilities without a content security bypass will be assessed at a lower severity level than those with a bypass.

## Description:
This occurs when you create a `custom link` with the `javascript://%0aalert(1)` through a [stripe app](https://marketplace.stripe.com/apps/custom-links). And, It gives a **CSP refused executing error** on clicking the custom link.

## Steps To Reproduce:
1. Install this `Custom Link` app:- https://marketplace.stripe.com/apps/custom-links
2. Now, Go to your products and then create a `Custom Link` with this `javascript://%0aalert(1)` as a link
{F2076228}

3. Then, Once you click on the custom link that you just created. It will doesn't execute because of CSP.
{F2076226}
4. You can verify this by opening your `Console`.

## Video POC:
{F2076227}

## Impact

If an attacker is able to bypass CSP then there is a possible XSS vulnerability in https://dashboard.stripe.com,.

activities.message:
Hi @saajanbhujel,

Thanks for the report! 

The present issue appears to be a self-XSS, which is not directly exploitable or would require convincing the user to copy/paste the JavaScript payload into the vulnerable field. In this case, it's no different from asking users to copy and paste malicious content into their browser's web developer console. Also it appears that the CSP policy is performing like it is supposed to and preventing the payload from being triggered.

As a result, we will be closing this report as informative. If you are able to leverage this into a practical exploitation scenario, we will be happy to reevaluate this report.

This will not have any impact on your Signal or Reputation score. We appreciate your effort and look forward to seeing more reports from you in the future.

Regards,

@h1_analyst_maximillian

Thanks @h1_analyst_maximillian, for your quick response :)

Sir, This issue is not a self-XSS because all the team members have access to the Stipe apps(`Custom Links`). And, If the admin installs any Stipe app then any team member or user can access the app.

**Also, If a member(`with any role`) adds any malicious javascript link within a `Custom Link` app, then all the members or users in the same org can access or view that link.**

Hi @saajanbhujel

Are you able to show the payload actually being triggered and not prevented by the CSP?

Thanks!

@h1_analyst_maximillian

@h1_analyst_maximillian,

**For demonstration,**
I created two users:
* One for `Admin`, and
* Second for `Attacker` with `Support Specialist` role

As I already installed the `Custom Link` then, this app is also visible for `Attacker`.

**So now, If an `Attacker` adds a malicious js payload or link through a `Custom Link` app, then an `Admin` is also able to view the link.**

So, This issue is not self-XSS.

With this technique, a `User` with any role can do this attack on other users or on admin within the same org.

You can also watch the POC video to know: `how a malicious user with any role can do this practical exploitation scenario`,
{F2076516}

Sir @h1_analyst_maximillian , 

@stripe already describes in their policy that:-
> Please note that we do accept and reward submissions for valid cross-site scripting vulnerabilities even if they are not accompanied by a bypass of our content security policy. Cross-site scripting vulnerabilities without a content security bypass will be assessed at a lower severity level than those with a bypass.

You can check **Other Notes on Submission Eligibility** section on stripe's policy page:- https://hackerone.com/stripe?type=team#:~:text=Other%20Notes%20on%20Submission%20Eligibility

Hi @saajanbhujel 

We have reopened the report and apologize for the inconvenience that this has caused you.

Kind regards,

@h1_analyst_maximillian

Thank you @h1_analyst_maximillian sir for reopening the report :)

Although, I normally don't report XSS until it properly executes. Also, This is the first time, I reported an XSS that is not executing. And, I was so confused about this issue but after doing some googling, I found that this is happening because of CSP.

Here, When I entered `javascript:alert()` in the Link then this redirects to me https://dashboard.stripe.com/products/javascript:alert() without any error. But, When I replaced my the Link with `javascript://%0aalert(1)` then, this time it shows me a CSP error which indicates that "The link is trying to execute the JS but due to the content security it's not executing any JS".

Have A Good Day!

Best regards,
Saajan Bhujel

Hi @saajanbhujel,
Thank you for your report! I just wanted to update you that we're taking a look at this internally and hope to have an update for you soon.
Best,
@grazingllama

Hi @saajanbhujel,
Thanks again for your report! We think we've fixed the issue, would you mind taking another look to confirm?
Best,
@grazingllama

Yes, @grazingllama,

Now, If we use previous custom links`javascript://%0aalert()`, then nothing executes which means that the issue is no more exploitable.
{F2102046}

I have also tried some other payloads(like: `javascript://%0dalert()` and `javascript:/**/%0aalert()`) but I wasn't able to bypass it.

So, I confirm that the XSS issue is fixed.
Thank you again for your report. We're going to review your report and get back to you soon on bounty information!

Hi @saajanbhujel,
Thanks for validating our fix. Even though this report did not demonstrate a CSP bypass, we would like to award you a bounty of $2,000 for helping us ensure our defenses against XSS are robust, and because this report demonstrated a flaw in a core security control of Stripe Apps, which is to prevent apps from running JavaScript outside their sandbox. We look forward to receiving more reports from you in the future!
Best,
@grazingllama
Thank you so much Stripe team for the amazing bounty.

Hello @grazingllama,

Can we disclose this report?

Hi @saajanbhujel, 
Before we begin the disclosure process, wed like to provide you information about our process.

Per [our program terms](https://hackerone.com/stripe?type=team#user-content-terms-and-conditions), we ask that you limit disclosure to only the contents to be inserted into the public HackerOne report. Also, please be aware that either party may revoke or decline the disclosure request at any time.

Before disclosing the report via HackerOne, we would like to:

1. Verify report metadata (report title, severity, weakness, etc).
2. Provide a summary of the report if the issue is considered high or critical severity after metadata is verified.

High and critical severity issues will receive a limited disclosure while medium and lower severity issues will be fully disclosed. For the report metadata, we will make adjustments at our discretion but please let us know if you have any concerns about our adjustments.

If you have any follow up comments after disclosure about this report, please open another report on HackerOne with Disclosure Followup in the title.

Please let us know if this sounds good to you and we can proceed with the next steps!
Best,
@grazingllama

Hello @grazingllama,

I agree to fully disclose this report.
